header.title: The Scroll of Set (Issue 124, Volume XVIII-5)
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Black Magic, Setianism

central_thesis: This compilation of articles from 'The Scroll of Set' elucidates the Temple of Set's philosophy, magical practices, and internal discourse in October 1992. The core system centers on the individual's self-deification (Xeper), achieved through the conscious understanding and manipulation of 'Darkness' (the potential of all Becoming) and 'Runa' (the unknown forces shaping individual experience). Practical applications involve personal and group rituals, Great Black Magic (GBM), and Lesser Black Magic (LBM) to foster isolate intelligence and manifest individual will, while navigating internal challenges like envy and external relationships with other occult traditions.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] A Few Words from the Editor
structure_content.summary: The editor provides logistical information for the upcoming Conclave and encourages Setians to submit articles to foster communal sharing of ideas and insights for individual and collective growth within the Temple.

Don Webb III° outlines a ritual involving chamber preparation, bell ringing, lighting the Black Flame, opening the Gate, Invocation of Set, a Graal ceremony, elemental summoning of historical figures associated with witchcraft, and a 'Work' phase culminating in interaction with 'the Black Man of the Woods' to write names in his Book and receive comfort, delight, and wisdom. This rite serves as an operative re-creation of the rites of the land to bring forth 'the Promise of the Lord of this World'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Thoughts on Envy and Competition Between Setians
structure_content.summary: Vesa Iitti II° explores envy as a 'negative emotion' that hinders individual Xeper, contrasting it with LaVey's view of envy as a motivator. The author advocates for cooperation among Setians as the optimal environment for individual Becoming, stressing that personal growth is an individual journey, not a competition.

Nino Wächter I° reflects on unconscious arrogance among Initiates and concludes that feelings of envy or jealousy, while persistent, can be consciously controlled through observation and understanding. The author emphasizes the importance of mutual support for navigating the path of Xeper.

Maharani Parivarta I° discusses the paradoxical nature of the universe as both ordered and chaotic, where truth is relative and 'meaning' can limit new experiences. The article advocates for maintaining an open mind, perpetual questioning, and rejecting fixed dogmas to facilitate growth and perception of constant change.

Don Webb III° offers a poetic reflection on eternal love and existence beyond death, portraying the self as a 'living flame' in 'eternal space darker than abyss above', hinting at an immortality that transcends conventional death.

Ruth Nielsen III° defines 'Darkness' as the 'potential of all that is Becoming' and 'the unseen of the past, the unspoken of the present and the yet unperceived from the future', directly linking it to the Xepera Xeper Xeperu formula. The article emphasizes that this concept is fundamental to Setian Black Magic, requiring concrete manifestation and sustained effort for true Xeper, not just mystical experience, to achieve self-knowledge and the surfacing of the Higher Self.

An anonymous narrative poem where saguaro cacti, seemingly passive, perform subtle magic to transform their human 'captors' (those who steal them for status symbols), leading them to rediscover forgotten language, nature, and deeper truths, eventually reaching for the 'secrets' of the wider sky.

Eve Taggart I° reviews a fictional sequel to 'Wuthering Heights', praising its adherence to the original tone and characterization of Heathcliff, and highlighting the book's expression of 'Satanic sentiments' worthy of his elemental nature.

Robert S. Freriks II° draws parallels between martial arts and occultism, noting shared characteristics like secrecy, discipline, and division into styles. He argues that martial arts benefit Setians by strengthening will, physical control, mental focus, and developing 'Ki', serving as a metaphor for cultivating the inner 'warrior spirit' crucial for Xeper.

Don Webb III° discusses the interplay of Will, Runa (unseen forces moving individuals), and Xeper. He suggests that while Runa draws individuals to Initiatory experiences, conscious application of 'isolate intelligence' is required to make use of these experiences for Xeper. Practical steps include consciously seeking new experiences, transforming present actions into encounters with the Unknown, and opening oneself to the transpersonal past.

Ruth Nielsen III° details a group working focused on self-knowledge and will to effect change. Behemoth symbolizes vast, intense creative energy. The ritual involves invoking Set/Nepthys, a Graal Ceremony, and a Behemoth Conjuration where participants focus their will and desires on a wax image, followed by individual reflection in a 'darkened closet' representing the Abyss.

structure_content.chapter_title: [13] Additional Report on 7/18 International Working: Transformation
structure_content.summary: Carmel Hind II° and Jennifer Hunter II° report on a synchronous international working aimed at 'pushing' transformation. The ritual used a bind Rune (Hagalas, Lagus, Isa, Kenas) formed into a sigil, followed by traditional opening rites, anointing, and setting the sigil aflame. Participants experienced a build-up of energy and a sense of cleansing.

structure_content.chapter_title: [14] GBM with Magical Circle and Triangle of Evocation
structure_content.summary: Bret Cagle II° describes his modifications to Thelemic magical circles and triangles for Great Black Magic (GBM) workings, primarily to enhance understanding of Xeper, Remanifestation, and the reality of Set. He outlines three formulas: for liberation from 'natural order', for separation from the 'cosmic all' (microcosm to macrocosm), and for alternating perspectives leading to a 'exeophrenic state' of consciousness. Tools like black glass mirrors and alchemical symbols are used for visions and evocations.

Chad Ian Miller I° philosophically and mathematically explores creation, the origin of the universe, and the paradox of 'zero divided by zero'. He proposes that if 'nothingness divided by nothingness can give anything', this could be a 'scientific proof of magic', leading to an LBM technique of visualizing desire forming 'out of nothingness' through mental application of this 'equation'.

Bret Cagle II° reinterprets Choronzon ('The Disperser of Human Consciousness') not as an adversary but as a 'friend' and 'neter' assisting the Black Magician in transcending human limitations and dispersing lower qualities, thereby enhancing Xeper and Remanifestation. The author seeks to contact the 'vampyric being' within the higher æthyrs.

Eulit Hinson II°'s poem evokes the mysteries of ancient Egypt ('Khem'), a land of 'black' or hidden knowledge, where the Sphinx guards secrets leading to 'unbounded life' and 'everlasting life', a journey away from worldly strife.

Sekhmet II° argues that supporting the Temple of Set as an organization and participating in collective creation is essential for individual Xeper. The author criticizes those who undermine the Temple, viewing it as counterproductive to the individual's magical efforts and indicative of a lack of understanding of the Great Work and the Word of Set.

Bret Cagle II° describes a GBM working to create a familiar spirit from a beloved pet. This involves choosing a mythological image (e.g., Cerberus for a Rottweiler) harmonious with the pet's characteristics, designing a working based on Thoth Deck Atu, invoking Anubis, and 'binding' the image to the pet. Frequent interaction with the 'spirit' further develops the talismanic image.
The editor encourages readers to provide feedback on the varied ideas presented in the Scroll of Set, promoting interaction and dispelling the myth that important issues receive less feedback.

Michael A. Aquino VI° announces the completion of the Third Edition of his 'Church of Satan' history, detailing new chapters, appendices, revisions, and reformatting. He provides ordering information for both the complete book and an update packet for Second Edition holders.

This section explains the Temple of Set's Articles of Incorporation and By-Laws, specifically highlighting recent revisions concerning membership in other religious or initiatory organizations (by-laws #2.02 and #2.03) and their relocation to the 'Ruby Tablet'.

A new policy for semi-formal dress at Temple functions is introduced to maintain decorum and prevent disruptive situations. Specific guidelines for gentlemen and ladies are provided, with provisions for alternate standards communicated in advance.

structure_content.chapter_title: [24] The Temple of Set and the O.T.O.
structure_content.summary: This article details the rationale behind the by-laws on dual membership, specifically addressing a concern from the O.T.O. USA leadership regarding the O.T.O.'s claim as a religion. The author argues that the O.T.O.'s religious classification is a legal maneuver rather than genuine conviction and that the Temple of Set's policies are not 'targeted' but based on its own philosophy.

structure_content.chapter_title: [25] Is the Temple of Set Pagan?
structure_content.summary: This article examines the definition of 'pagan' and argues that the Temple of Set is authentically polytheistic—as each Initiate is their own god/dess—and therefore pagan. It contrasts this view with monotheistic perspectives and the 'post-75 Church of Satan' which is described as monotheistic but fitting the 'hedonist' definition of pagan.

structure_content.chapter_title: [26] From a Letter to a Friend
structure_content.summary: A quoted philosophical letter by Albert Camus discusses the differing responses to existential despair: one accepting injustice and siding with 'the gods', and the other choosing justice to fight eternal injustice and create human meaning in a world without ultimate meaning.

The author discusses the 300th anniversary of the Salem witch trials, criticizing the city's romanticization of this 'cruel, barbaric, and disgraceful episode'. It is posited that the Temple of Set's 'Black Mass' should aim to expose 'enshrined falsehoods' and serve as a reminder of what happens when truth and justice are neglected.

key_concepts.definition: The process of self-deification or Coming into Being, central to Setian philosophy, involving sustained effort and productivity at an evolutionary level. It is enhanced by understanding and utilizing forces like Darkness and Runa.

An unknown force or set of phenomena that impacts and moves individuals to Initiatory experiences, influencing their lives. Conscious application of isolate intelligence is required to utilize these experiences for Xeper.

The potential of all that is Becoming; the unseen aspects of the past, the unspoken of the present, and the yet unperceived from the future. It is a fundamental Mystery in Setian thought, linked to the subconscious and viewed as a vast, real energy field, not an empty void, to be concretely manifested for self-knowledge and the Higher Self.

A symbol of vast, intense, and transformative creative energy, often portrayed as a raging elephant. In Setian workings, it represents powerful inner resources focused by will to specific personal ends for self-knowledge and manifestation in the concrete realm.

A core symbol in Setianism, representing individual isolate intelligence and the spark of divinity within each Initiate. It is lit in rituals and symbolizes the burning core of one's being and potential for Xeper.

In the Salem Witch Rite, a cup brought into being by 'noble and evil deeds', containing 'red bread and red wine like blood', representing the 'Power of the Promise of the Lord of this World'. In other contexts, the 'Graal Ceremony' focuses on integrity, courage, daring, and sharing the experience.

A form of magical working within the Temple of Set, often involving complex ritual structures, symbols, and focused intent for personal transformation, understanding of Set, and the manifestation of Xeper.
A more direct, perhaps less elaborate, form of magic focused on manifesting specific desires in the subjective universe, such as using 'zero divided by zero' as an equation for creation.

The unique, self-aware consciousness of each individual, distinct from the 'cosmic all'. It is the foundation of Setian philosophy, emphasizing individual Becoming and the exercise of personal will for self-deification.

Reinterpreted as the 'Disperser of Human Consciousness' and a 'friend' or 'neter' in Setian GBM. It is seen as an entity that assists the Black Magician in transcending the limitations of the 'bestial human' and dispersing lower qualities to enhance Xeper and Remanifestation, leading to a self-ordered existence.

practical_system.description: The practical system of the Temple of Set, as presented, is an eclectic and highly individualized approach to Black Magic, fundamentally aimed at personal Xeper (self-deification). It involves conscious self-transformation, the development of 'isolate intelligence', and the direct application of will to manipulate subjective and objective reality. Rituals often combine traditional magical elements (e.g., invocations, elemental summonings, symbolic tools) with Setian-specific concepts like the Black Flame and the 'Mystery of Darkness'. The system emphasizes introspection, continuous learning, and sharing insights, with a focus on achieving concrete results and a deeper understanding of one's true will. Lesser Black Magic (LBM) includes direct manifestation techniques, while Great Black Magic (GBM) involves more complex workings for profound personal and cosmological understanding.
tools: Black Flame of Set (as a physical flame and symbolic concept)
Altar (often round, decorated with crystals, gemstones, brass censor, Grails)
Magical Circle (modified Thelemic, with Setian names/words)
Triangle of Evocation (with black glass mirror, alchemical symbols, Setian names)
Runes (Hagalas, Lagus, Isa, Kenas, combined into sigils)
Wax image of Behemoth (red elephant candle)
Incense (sultry, wedding incense with Damiana, sandalwood, musk)
rituals: Salem Witch Rite (invocation of Set, Graal, elemental summoning, Black Man of the Woods interaction)
Behemoth Working (harnessing vast creative energy for self-knowledge and manifestation)
International Transformation Working (using Runes to 'push' change)
GBM with Magical Circle and Triangle of Evocation (modifications for Xeper, Remanifestation, self-liberation, separation, and simultaneous perception)
Creation of Familiar Spirits (magically enhancing pets with talismanic images)
LBM: Mathematical Equation method (visualizing desires forming 'out of nothingness')

relevant_quotes.text: Darkness is the potential of all that is Becoming. Is the unseen of the past, the unspoken of the present and the yet unperceived from the future.

The Black Man of the Woods appears with his Book. He beckons each of the participants to the altar, symbolically draws blood from their wrists and lets them write their names in his Book. After they write their names, he warms the Book in the Black Flame and says: “The Pact is sealed. The Powers of the Sabbath are now yours."

If there is something which you wish to create, or something you wish to accomplish, merely hold out your hands in front of you and concentrate on the space between your hands. Out of the empty space visualize that which you desire forming (“becoming”) out of nothingness. Will in your mind for that thing you wish to occur and perform mentally the equation, either mathematically or symbolically. Conclude the ritual with a clear, sharp image of that which you desire occurring in your subjective universe. The effects are staggering, as it contains all of the higher principles of magical operation.
To 'worship' Set in this sense is simply the recognition and appreciation of a profound principle that makes possible all sense of identity. So we are not monotheistic.
This cup is brought into being by your most noble and evil deeds. This bread is the Power of the Promise of the Lord of this World. It is the red bread and red wine like blood.

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of articles is highly relevant for understanding the foundational and evolving philosophical, ethical, and practical dimensions of the Temple of Set in the early 1990s. It demonstrates the order's emphasis on individual self-deification (Xeper) through conscious effort, introspection, and magical practice, while also addressing internal community dynamics and external perceptions. The detailed ritual descriptions provide insight into operative Setian magic, and the discussions on 'Darkness', 'Runa', and 'Choronzon' reveal nuanced interpretations of key occult concepts within the Setian framework. It also contextualizes the Temple of Set's identity in relation to other occult groups like the O.T.O. and the Church of Satan.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates and advanced practitioners of the Temple of Set, seeking to deepen their understanding of Setian philosophy and refine their magical practice. Academics and researchers specializing in Western Esotericism, modern occultism, and new religious movements (especially Left-Hand Path traditions) would also find this document valuable for its insights into the inner workings and intellectual discourse of the Temple of Set.
